history.content:
If you are comfortable with the material in 70 (basic proofs and probability), you should be fine.

___________________________________

Answer2: I did this in my freshmen year and it is doable.
If you are comfortable with the material in 70 (basic proofs and probability), you should be fine.

I'm a transfer student going into my first semester at Berkeley. I maintained a pretty busy schedule throughout community college with a 4.0. In my last semester there, I was taking 3 CS classes and one intro Engineering class, while working about 35 hours a week between a web development job with the state, a software engineering job on campus, and a private tutoring position (the jobs weren't high pressure but they were a big time commitment). Also, I have completed the entire math series, but honestly forgot a good deal of what I learned in DE, linear algebra, and calc 3. I felt like I was stretching myself last semester but I still did well, so that would probably be my limit.

If I were to just focus on classes (no work, partying, maybe only in one or two clubs), would this be manageable course load for me? Is this something EECS students do often?

Thank you!
history.subject: Is CS 61A + CS 70 + EE 16A + UD Humanities (a rather easy one) too heavy of a course load for me?

history.content:
